review.title: Iterated Ontology Revision by Reinterpretation
review.abstract: Iterated applications of belief change operators are essential for different scenarios such as that of ontology evolution where new information is not presented at once but only in piecemeal fashion within a sequence. I discuss iterated applications of so called reinterpretation operators that trace conflicts between ontologies back to the ambiguous of symbols and that provide conflict resolution strategies with bridging axioms. The discussion centers on adaptations of the classical iteration postulates according to Darwiche and Pearl. The main result of the paper is that reinterpretation operators fulfill the postulates for sequences containing only atomic triggers. For complex triggers, a fulfillment is not guaranteed and indeed there are different reasons for the different postulates why they should not be fulfilled in the particular scenario of ontology revision with well developed ontologies.

sections.heading: 5 Related Work
sections.text: The reinterpretation operators are constructed in a similar way to those of Delgrande and Schaub (Delgrande and Schaub 2003), but differ in that they are defined not only for the statement logic, but also for DLs (and FOLs). Furthermore, I consider other stronger forms of bridging axioms than the implications of (Delgrande and Schaub 2003).Bridging axioms are special mappings that are used in the reinterpretation of the operator as tools for implementing the ontology revision. However, one can also consider mappings themselves as objects of revision (Qi, Ji and Haase 2009; Meilicke and Stuckenschmidt 2009); a particularly interesting case of the mapping revision comes into play with mappings used in the ontology-based data access paradigm (Calvanese et al. 2009). These mappings are intended to elevate data from the relational Ds to the ontology level.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In the paper, iterative applications of reinterpretation operators were discussed, which served to handle conflicts due to the ambiguous use of symbols in related and well-developed ontologies. Re-interpretation operators can also be used to resolve consistencies, not due to ambiguity, but due to incorrect information - and in fact, the related revision operators in (Delgrande and Schaub 2003) do not speak of ambiguity. But reinterpretation operators cannot be used to resolve inconsistencies that clearly cannot be explained by ambiguity: namely consistencies due to differing limitations of the sender and the recipient with respect to the number of possible objects in the domain (this was referred to as reinterpretation compatibility in (O � zc � ep 2008)). The reinterpretation for triggering words proved to be fulfilled (adapted versions of) classical iteration operations as a guarantee for the reconstruction of symbols used in the 1994 reconstruction and Pearl reconstruction.
